qas.question: What type of material is used to make CDs?
What size is the diameter of the center hole in a CD?
How long does it take to stamp out one CD?
What is the term for the center hole in a CD?
How large is the screw that forces the plastic into the cavity?
How long does it take the plastic to cool?
What is the robotic arm called?
What is a hydraulic press made out of?

context: Replicated CDs are mass-produced initially using a <a0_0>hydraulic press<a0_0/>. Small granules of heated <a1_0><b8_0>raw polycarbonate plastic<b8_0/><a1_0/> are fed into the press. A screw forces the liquefied plastic into the mold cavity. The mold closes with a metal stamper in contact with the disc surface. The plastic is allowed to cool and harden. Once opened, the disc substrate is removed from the mold by <b9_0>a robotic arm<b9_0/>, and a <a2_0><b5_0>15 mm<a2_0/> diameter<b5_0/> center hole (called <b7_0>a <a4_0>stacking ring<b7_0/><a4_0/>) is created. The time it takes to "stamp" one CD is usually <a3_0><b6_0>two to three seconds<b6_0/><a3_0/>.
